If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Page not found Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic | Mental Health Commission of Canada If you are in distress, please contact your nearest distress centre. If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. 2031 Ce que nous faisons Aidants Enfants et jeunes Norme Étudiants Santé mentale à la petite enfance Diversité Cybersanté mentale Premières nations, Inuits et Métis Santé mentale et usage de substances La santé mentale dans le système judiciaire Accès à des soins de santé mentale de qualité Soutien par les pairs Rétablissement Aînés Stigmatisation et discrimination Stigmatisation structurelle Prévention du suicide Santé mentale en milieu de travail Norme nationale Secteur Sante Main d’œuvre en quête d’emploi Formation et ressources Rapports CSMC Stratégie en Matière de Santé Mentale pour le Canada La Stratégie en matière de santé mentale pour le Canada : Une perspective axée sur les jeunes Faire valoir les arguments en faveur des investissements dans le système de santé mentale du Canada à l’aide de considérations économiques Indicateurs de la santé mentale pour le Canada Chez Soi Cadre d’action (2017–2022) Bibliothèque Entraînement Premier Soins en Santé Mentale L’esprit Au Travail Centre de formation SPARK LA TÊTE HAUTE L’esprit curieux, postsecondaire L`esprit au travail premiers intervenants Webinaires Trousse d’outils Trousse d’outils appui du gouvernement Trousse de mobilisation Trousse d’outils en prévention du suicide Trousse pratique pour aider les employeurs à créer des milieux de travail inclusifs Trousse d’outils Prendre soin des travailleurs de la santé Formation en ligne sur la santé et la sécurité psychologiques Cybersanté mentale Trousse d’évaluation du risque suicidaire : une ressource à l’intention des travailleurs et des organisations de soins de santé Bulletin de la CSMC Centre des médias Avis aux médias Communiqués Discours Déclarations Évènements Affiner par zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Page introuvable Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. If it is an emergency, call 9-1-1 or go to your local emergency department Pre Header Contact Us English Français MHCC Follow Us Block Facebook Twitter Youtube LinkedIn Instagram Read our Newsletter Who We Are Our People Board Executive Leadership Team Directors Careers and Opportunities MHCC Networks Youth Council Hallway Group Former Advisory Committees Corporate Reports Annual Reports MHCC Strategic Plan 2021 - 2031 What We Do Caregiving Children and Youth Post-Secondary Students Standard Early Childhood Mental Health Diversity e-Mental Health First Nations, Inuit and Métis Mental Health and Substance Use Mental Health and the Justice System Access to Quality Mental Health Care Peer Support Recovery Seniors Stigma and Discrimination Structural Stigma Suicide Prevention Workplace The Standard Workplace Healthcare Aspiring Workforce Training & Resources MHCC Reports Mental Health Strategy for Canada MHS: A Youth Perspective Case for Investing MH Indicators for Canada At Home A Framework for Action (2017–2022) Library Training MHFA The Working Mind SPARK Headstrong Youth Summit The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary The Working Mind First Responders Webinars Toolkits Government Engagement Toolkit Caregiver Mobilization Toolkit Suicide Prevention Toolkits A Practical Toolkit to Help Employers Build an Inclusive Workforce Caring for Healthcare Toolkit Online training in psychological health and safety e-Mental Health Suicide Risk Assessment Toolkit: A Resource for Healthcare Workers and Organizations Newsletter Media Centre Advisories Releases Speeches Statements Events Narrow by Focus Area Breadcrumb Home > Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Share Facebook Twitter LinkedIn If you are experiencing distress, please call your local crisis centre. Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. zone de mise au point Fil d'Arianne Accueil > Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Carrefour de ressources : Santé mentale et bien-être durant la pandémie de COVID-19 Partagez Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Si vous êtes en détresse, veuillez contacter le centre d’aide le plus proche. Devant l’évolution rapide de la pandémie de COVID-19, nous vivons tous, à divers degrés, une réaction normale à un événement anormal. Bien que la Commission de la santé mentale du Canada ne soit pas un fournisseur de services de santé mentale et qu’elle ne puisse malheureusement pas répondre aux demandes d’individus et de cliniciens, elle est néanmoins en mesure de fournir de l’information sélectionnée fiable et fondée sur des données probantes. Durant cette période d’anxiété et de stress élevés, il est plus important que jamais de préserver son bien-être mental. Cela se fait notamment en endiguant la marée d’information non essentielle et en limitant sa consommation d’actualités. La CSMC se consacre à diffuser de l’information et des ressources crédibles au sujet du maintien de la santé mentale en cette période de crise ainsi qu’à aider les gens à composer avec une maladie mentale dans ce contexte nouveau. Pour de plus amples renseignements concernant la réaction du Canada à la COVID-19, visitez le site web du gouvernement du Canada. Policy Maker Read more Healthcare Provider Read more Employer Read more Individual Read more KEY PRIORITIES Suicide Prevention Every day, 10 people in Canada die by suicide. The MHCC is working to build capacity across the country to address this silent crisis. From grass-roots projects to evidence-informed training, reducing suicides means empowering and supporting people to effectively intervene where they live and work. Read more Mental Health and Substance Use As we grow to better understand the co-occurring nature of mental health problems and substance use, there is a call to work more closely on providing integrated care. The MHCC, in partnership with CCSA and others, have started work that explores the important intersections between the mental health and substance use sectors to advance policy and program change across Canada. Read more Population-based initiatives The MHCC is working to improve mental health services, supports and policies for diverse populations, including immigrant, refugee, racialized and ethno-cultural groups, people in the LGBTQ2S community, youth, seniors, Indigenous populations, people in minority language situations, and public safety officers. All initiatives are centred in recovery, rooted in a person-centred approach. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website. Newsletter Contact Us Covid-19 Hub Français About About What We Do Careers and Opportunities Media Centre Training Mental Health First Aid The Working Mind HEADSTRONG The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary Other Training Events Blogs Resources Roots of Hope: A community suicide prevention projectLEARN MORE Discover the 11 early adopter communities from across the country! Discover Mental Health At Home Read More At Work Read More Policy & Research Read More Training Many people with mental health issues experience stigma. One of the best ways to break down stigma is through contact-based education. It’s important that people get support as soon as possible when experiencing mental health issues. We all need to be educated to be able to recognize symptoms of mental health issues in ourselves and others. Our training programs are designed to increase your mental health literacy, reduce the stigma of mental illness, and provide you with the skills and knowledge to help you better manage potential or developing mental health problems in yourself, your family members, your friends, or your colleagues. Learn more about our training programs and register for one today. Discover Mental Health At Home Read More At Work Read More Policy & Research Read More Training Many people with mental health issues experience stigma. One of the best ways to break down stigma is through contact-based education. It’s important that people get support as soon as possible when experiencing mental health issues. We all need to be educated to be able to recognize symptoms of mental health issues in ourselves and others. Our training programs are designed to increase your mental health literacy, reduce the stigma of mental illness, and provide you with the skills and knowledge to help you better manage potential or developing mental health problems in yourself, your family members, your friends, or your colleagues. Learn more about our training programs and register for one today. Newsletter Contact Us Covid-19 Hub Français About About What We Do Careers and Opportunities Media Centre Training Mental Health First Aid The Working Mind HEADSTRONG The Inquiring Mind Post-Secondary Other Training Events Blogs Resources Home › Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Resource Hub: Mental health and wellness during the COVID-19 pandemic Given the ever-changing events around the COVID-19 pandemic, we are all experiencing varying degrees of a normal reaction to an abnormal event. While we are not a mental health services provider, and we regrettably cannot respond to requests from individuals or clinicians, we can offer curated, evidence-based information that you can trust. In times of high anxiety and stress, it’s more important than ever to safeguard your mental wellness. That includes stemming the tide of non-essential information and paring down your news consumption. At the Mental Health Commission of Canada, our commitment is to share credible information and resources about maintaining mental health during this time of crisis, and supporting people managing a mental illness in this new context. For up-to-date information about Canada’s COVID-19 response, please visit the Government of Canada website.
